columns.text: In this problem, we need to determine whether the supplier will approve the credit, and calculate the break-even probability of default.

**Part a)** The customer ordered eight high-bypass turbine engines, which increase fuel economy from Air Spares suppliers. Suppose this is a one-time transaction.

 Let us denote with $\pi$ the probability that one of the $200$ new customers will not pay for the goods to the supplier. So, $\pi=\frac{1}{200}=0.005$. 

Here we have that the variable costs are $v=\$1.25$ million per unit, credit price is $P=\$1.63$ million per each.

Substituting given data in the formula for NPV, we get that the NPV of granting credit is 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{NPV}&=-v+\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot P}{1+R}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{(1-0.005)\cdot \$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}}{1+0.018}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{0.995\cdot\$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million} }{1.018}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{\$1.62185\hspace{1mm}\text{million} }{1.018}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\$1.593173\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\\[15pt]
&=0.343173\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\\[15pt]
&=\$343,173\\[15pt]
\end{align*}$$

With $1.8$ percent rate of default, net present value is approximately $\$343,173$. So , credit should be granted.

**Part b)**  When a firm grants a credit to new customers, it risks its variable costs. For a new customer, therefore, the credit can be approved even if the probability of default is high. 

The break-even probability of default can be calculated  by setting the NPV equal to zero and solving for $\pi$, as follows 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{NPV}&=-v+\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot P}{1+R}\\[15pt]
0&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot \$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}}{1+0.018}\\[15pt]
\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}&=\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot \$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}}{1.018}\\[15pt]
\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\cdot 1.018&=(1-\pi)\cdot \$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\\[15pt]
\$1.2725\hspace{1mm}\text{million}&=(1-\pi)\$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\\[15pt]
1-\pi&=\frac{\$1.2725\hspace{1mm}\text{million}}{\$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}}\\[15pt]
1-\pi&=0.781\\[15pt]
\Longrightarrow\pi&=1-0.781\\[15pt]
\pi&=0.219\hspace{2mm}\text{or}\hspace{2mm}21.9\%\\
\end{align*}$$

You  should not accept the order if the default probability was higher than $21.9\%$.

**Part c)** If a new customer who does not fulfill the obligations for the first time will stay a customer forever and never default, then the cash in flow is change. The cash in flow is now product of $(1-\pi)$ and difference between sales price and variable cost.  We have to use the selling price minus the variable cost because we will have to make another engine for the buyer in one period. In addition, this cash inflow is now perpetual, so the NPV now will be 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{NPV}&=-v+\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot (P-v)}{R}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{(1-0.005)\cdot (\$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million})}{0.018}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{0.995\cdot\$0.38\hspace{1mm}\text{million} }{0.018}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{\$0.3781\hspace{1mm}\text{million} }{0.018}\\[15pt]
&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\$21.055\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\\[15pt]
&=\$19.75555556\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\\[15pt]
&=\$19,755,555.56\\
\end{align*}$$
The company should fill the order.

Then, the breakeven default probability under these assumptions in step 5 is: 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{NPV}&=-v+\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot (P-v)}{R}\\[15pt]
0&=-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}+\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot (\$1.63\hspace{1mm}\text{million}-\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million})}{0.018}\\[15pt]
\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}&=\frac{(1-\pi)\cdot \$0.38\hspace{1mm}\text{million}}{0.018}\\[15pt]
1-\pi&=\frac{\$1.25\hspace{1mm}\text{million}\cdot 0.018}{\$0.38\hspace{1mm}\text{million}}\\[15pt]
1-\pi&=0.059\\[15pt]
\Longrightarrow\pi&=0.941\hspace{2mm}\text{or}\hspace{2mm}94.1\%
\end{align*}$$
The order will not be accepted if the default probability was higher than $94.1\%$. This default probability is much higher than in part (b) because the customer may become a repeat customer.

**Part d)**  It is assumed that the customer who regularly paid his bills to the supplier in the past will be a regular payer in the future. This implies that if someone fails to meet the obligations when the credit is first approved, then they will be a good buyer far in the future, and the potential gains from future business are greater than the potential losses from approving the loan for the first time.
